channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: U.S. Strike on Taliban Leader Is Seen as a Message to Pakistan
item.description: President Obama described Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour’s death as an “important milestone,” but it also illustrated the tangled relationship between Washington and Islamabad.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: News Analysis: Despite Obama’s Moves, Asian Nations Skeptical of U.S. Commitment
item.media:description: President Obama during a news conference with President Tran Dai Quang of Vietnam on Monday in Hanoi.
item.description: The American political mood has darkened toward longtime alliances and international trade. For Asian allies, this means the U.S. might pivot away.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Vietnam Arms Embargo to Be Fully Lifted, Obama Says in Hanoi
item.description: The president’s announcement that the United States was “fully lifting” the decades-old ban on lethal weapons sales came at a news conference in Hanoi.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: West Bank Journal: A Window Into the West Bank’s ‘Wildest, Most Violent’ Areas
item.media:description: Hanamel Dorfman, 21, beside the rubble of a house that was demolished this month by the Israeli authorities in Yishuv Hadaat, a Jewish settlement outpost in the West Bank.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: A documentary by the Israeli-American filmmaker Shimon Dotan, “The Settlers,” shown in Israel for the first time on Monday, examines a fringe group known as the “hilltop youth.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens of Yemeni Army Recruits
item.media:description: The scene of the suicide bombing on Monday in Aden, Yemen.
item.description: A local branch of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the blast in the southern city of Aden, one of the deadliest since Yemen’s civil war began.
item.dc:creator: SAEED AL-BATATI and KAREEM FAHIM
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula

item.title: Austrian Far-Right Candidate Norbert Hofer Narrowly Loses Presidential Vote
item.media:description: Alexander Van der Bellen won Austria’s presidential election on support from city dwellers — particularly Vienna, which voted 61 percent for him — and women.
item.description: Mr. Hofer lost to Alexander Van der Bellen, a 72-year-old economics professor and former Green Party leader.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Calls of Justice for Aboriginal Women Echo Down Canada’s Highway of Tears
item.media:description: A billboard along Highway 16. The stretch of road is known as the Highway of Tears because dozens of women, mostly aboriginal, have been murdered or have disappeared in the area.
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced an inquiry into a series of disappearances and murders, part of a promise to renew the country’s relationship with its indigenous citizens.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Transcript Suggests a Plot Behind Effort to Oust Brazilian President
item.description: A government minister appointed by Brazil’s new interim president said he would resign after excerpts of a conversation indicated he was trying to impede a corruption inquiry.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: Tunisian Islamic Party Re-elects Moderate Leader
item.media:description: Rachid Ghannouchi, right, the leader of the Ennahda party in Tunisia, and Abdelfattah Mourou, the vice president, on Friday at the party’s congress. On Monday, Mr. Ghannouchi won re-election with 800 of 1,058 ballots cast.
item.description: Rachid Ghannouchi has steered his party, Ennahda, away from its Islamist roots.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Powerful Iranian Council Selects Hard-Liner as Chairman
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ahmad Jannati in Tehran in 2012.
item.description: Ayatollah Ahmad Jannati, 89, was chosen to lead an assembly that would have the authority to pick the next supreme leader.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: As Obama Presses Vietnam on Rights, Activists Are Barred From Meeting
item.media:description: The audience at the convention center in Hanoi on Tuesday. About 2,300 Vietnamese cheered loudly when Mr. Obama appeared about 15 minutes later than originally scheduled.
item.description: The White House had requested the meeting as a signal to Vietnam’s Communist government that the United States cares about human rights in the country.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Greece Begins Moving Refugees Out of Idomeni Camp
item.media:description: The police intervened at a refugee camp near the Greek village of Idomeni on Tuesday.
item.description: About 8,000 migrants were living in squalid conditions in the encampment, hoping to be allowed to cross the border and head to Northern or Western Europe.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Carl Minzner on the Shift to Personalized Rule in China
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China reviewing troops in Tiananmen Square during a military parade on Sept. 3, 2015 celebrating victory over Japan at the end of World War Two.
item.description: Mr. Minzner, a law professor at Fordham University, argues that under President Xi Jinping the post-Mao drive toward institutionalized governance is waning.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: Gunmen Kill 3 Police Officers in Srinagar, India
item.media:description: Mourners gathered near the coffin of a police officer in Srinagar, Kashmir, on Monday. Gunmen killed three officers in two separate shootings.
item.description: The officers were killed in an area that has long been a source of conflict between India and Pakistan, with separatist militants claiming responsibility.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: The Hiroshima Mushroom Cloud That Wasn’t
item.media:description: The aftermath of the atomic bomb in Hiroshima on Aug. 6, 1945.
item.description: The image, a symbol of a city’s destruction that has been considered the moment a nuclear bomb hit, is actually of smoke from fires that followed.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM J. BROAD
item.category: The Making of the Atomic Bomb (Book)

item.title: British Restaurateur Sentenced to 6 Years After Peanut Allergy Death
item.description: The owner of a curry house was found guilty of manslaughter by gross negligence, and other offenses, over a fatal dish of chicken tikka masala.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Angelina Jolie Will Be Visiting Professor at London School of Economics
item.media:description: The actress Angelina Jolie Pitt, who is also a special envoy for the United Nations refugee agency, was in London last week.
item.description: The actress will be a guest lecturer in a master’s program that starts taking applicants in the fall at one of Britain’s most renowned institutions.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Israel Allows Building Supplies to Enter Gaza Again
item.media:description: Trucks loaded with bags of cement on Monday at the Kerem Shalom border crossing between Israel and southern Gaza.
item.description: The Israeli authorities lifted a suspension that had blocked work for more than a month on thousands of houses destroyed in the 2014 summer war.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: From Cuba to Miami by Providence and a Homemade Boat
item.media:description: Three Cuban refugees, from left, Yosvanys Chinea, Alierky Perez and Brayan Sanchez, looked out over Deering Channel on May 6 outside the Shrine of Our Lady of Charity in Miami.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: A motley group of Cuban refugees risked their lives at sea for five days to reach the United States and a new future. Many others are not so lucky.
item.dc:creator: LIZETTE ALVAREZ

item.title: David Cameron Says Leaving E.U. Would Hobble British Economy
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, and George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, addressed employees at the headquarters of a home-improvement chain in southern England on Monday.
item.description: The prime minister, citing a Treasury report, warned of a recession, a decline in the value of the pound, and half a million lost jobs.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Suicide Attacks Hit 2 Syrian Cities in Assad Stronghold, Killing Scores
item.description: The coordinated assaults on bus stations and part of a hospital brought the horrors of the country’s civil war into a region that had been relatively safe.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAHER SAMAAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Political Light Installation on Hong Kong Skyscraper Is Pulled
item.description: Organizers said they weren’t told that the display would have a countdown to 2047, when China’s promise of a high degree of autonomy for Hong Kong expires.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Iraqi Leader Announces Offensive to Retake Falluja From ISIS
item.media:description: Iraqi pro-government forces near Falluja on Monday. For months, militias and Iraqi security forces have surrounded Falluja, putting the city under a siege that has led to starvation and shortages of medicine.
item.description: Any ground battle to liberate the city, a stronghold of Sunni extremism that fell to the Islamic State more than two years ago, is likely to be long and bloody.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Thailand Dormitory Fire Kills at Least 17 Girls, Official Says
item.media:description: Rescue workers removed an injured student early Monday after a fire broke out at a school dormitory in northern Thailand.
item.description: The victims, ages 6 to 12, died after the blaze broke out around 11 p.m. at a school in northern Thailand, an Interior Ministry official said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Taiwan Drops Charges Against Protesters in Government Sit-In
item.media:description: Riot police officers clashing with protesters outside Taiwan’s cabinet building, in Taipei, the capital, in 2014.
item.description: The demonstrators had been charged in the takeover of Taiwan’s cabinet building in 2014 as part of the Sunflower Movement, a protest over closer China ties.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Obama Says Mullah Mansour, Taliban Leader, Was Killed in U.S. Strike
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, in an undated photo.
item.description: President Obama released a statement calling the killing of Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour in an American drone strike in Pakistan “an important milestone.”
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: What in the World: A Uniquely Korean Household Worry
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photo by donnichols/istock
item.description: Across South Korea, many people believe a common household appliance can kill if left on too long.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: For This Green Smoothie, the First Ingredient Is Frog
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Hintau Aliaksei/Shutterstock
item.description: In Peru and Bolivia, drinks made from the endangered Titicaca water frog are promoted as a cure for many ailments, without scientific support.
item.dc:creator: EVAN GERSHKOVICH

item.title: What in the World: China Offers Airport Security for Women, and Their Makeup
item.description: “Female Only” security lines are at four airports, in part so women are not frisked by men, but also because cosmetics require greater scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Australia’s Offshore Cruelty
item.media:description: Protesting in March outside the office of Australia’s immigration minister in Brisbane.
item.description: Scrap a policy that condemns refugees to a desperate and hopeless limbo.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Docs: The Shampoo Summit
item.description: In a hair salon in Israel, Arab and Jewish women find common ground … in a sink.
item.dc:creator: IRIS ZAKI

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Bertie Wooster v. Donald Trump
item.media:description: A protest in Birmingham, England, in February.
item.description: Britons like to believe that comic genius is protection from tyranny. They shouldn’t be too complacent.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
